step.context: \text{The given integral is similar to }\\ \quad I_E = \int (x-b)\cdot\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\cdot dx.\\ \text{If we therefore recommended the following}\\ \text{strategy for finding }I_E\text{, then would you}\\ \text{accept our recommendation?}
step.tex: \text{Apply integration by parts} \\ \begin{align} I_E &= \int (x-b)\cdot\sqrt{x^2+a^2} dx \\ &= (x-b)\int\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\cdot dx \\ &- \int \left[\frac{d}{dx}(x-b)\cdot\int\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\right]\cdot dx \\ &= (x-b)\int\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\cdot dx \\ &- \int\left(\int\sqrt{x^2+a^2} \cdot dx\right)\cdot dx \end{align}
step.reason: \text{If you apply integration by parts to }\\ \quad I_E = \int(x-b)\cdot\sqrt{x^2+a^2}\cdot dx\\ \text{then you will soon find that the resulting}\\ \text{integral is more complicated to solve than}\\ \text{the original one. Not what you want.}\\ \text{Life is easier if }(x-b) = A\dfrac{d}{dx}(x^2+a^2) + B.\\ \text{The original integral can then be broken}\\ \text{into ones that are easier to evaluate.}

\begin{align} t = x^2+3x-18 &\implies \dfrac{dt}{dx} = (2x+3) \\ \therefore\text{ if }(x-3) &= A\cdot (2x+3) + B \\ \text{then }A = \dfrac{1}{2}, B = -\dfrac{9}{2} \\ \implies (x-3) &= \dfrac{1}{2}\dfrac{dt}{dx} - \dfrac{9}{2} \\ \implies (x-3)\cdot dx &= \dfrac{dt}{2} - \dfrac{9}{2}\cdot dx \end{align}
